Had to pause near the end to affirm the nugget of wisdom. Worry never fixed anything (replace worry with diligence). Stress is only useful in short bursts, if at all. It's easy now for me to not worry, but it took a while to get there, and it might be one of the best things you ever learned to do, for many great reasons. You maintain clarity, your energy reserves last longer, and you may live a longer life with longevity also for various of your capacities. You just function better without too much stress and worry. And maybe most important - you'll be happier.

Only worry about what you can change.  That has been my philosophy since I was a child.  Given to me by a neighbor, old man Kennedy.  I cut his grass for years.

The wisdom you discussed at the end of not worrying about things when you’ve done the best you can does have its limits, though. And they apply, if anywhere, especially in space programs, as I know form personal experience. Every space program involves trade-offs, instances where you perhaps would like to do something, include something, devote more effort into something and you decide not to, for reasons of time, or money. Or perhaps your mass budget, power budget, link budget, or some other constraint, doesn’t allow it. You can strive for perfection, but you cannot achieve it by definition, because resources are limited and you mostly know very well where the weaknesses are. You think that you made the right choices in opting to go down one way and not another. But the proof of the pudding remains in the eating.

Hey @SmarterEveryDay ... that last little nugget of wisdom regarding only worrying about things you can control is a fundamental method to learning how to relax and enjoy life. My Mom once changed her flight booking to a 4 hour layover on purpose through Newark for her flight from Denver to Geneva because she was worried her bags wouldn't make her connecting flight on the regularly scheduled 2 hour layover. She also stressed out about her bags for the 3 months leading up to the flight. This got us talking about the need to only worry about things she can control (like setting 2 alarms clocks to ensure you wake up on time for the flight), and maybe also worrying about things "within your circle of influence" (like being friendly to the driver of the airport shuttle van in hopes that he'll help you out in case things go wrong), and definitely NOT worrying about things that are OUTSIDE of this circle of influence (which is outside of the circle of control). Life is too short to worry about things outside of your circle of influence (like worrying if it's going to rain tomorrow). What you can control is whether or not you have an umbrella ready, and if it rains, then it rains, and you're ready for it. Great video by the way. Thanks!

10:36 Destin, the gram is a unit of mass not, force (weight). In our everyday lives we mistakenly convert grams and kilograms to ounces and pounds, but in reality, we should be saying a gram or kilogram WEIGHS ..., not is equal to. The correct units of force are the Newton (kg m/s^2), and the smaller unit, Dyne (g cm/s^2).

5:29 Anastigmat broken down is:

1) an- from the Greek meaning not, or without.
2) astigmatism (-astigma-) a word coined by William Whewell in 1849 from a-, without or not, and stigma, spot, a defect of the eye or any optical instrument when it does not focus properly due to improper curvature.
3) the ending -t is added to indicate that the mirror exhibits this property.

Put them all together and they spell "mother", oops I meant anastigmat. LOL

There are many flaws in this design. There are no adequate solar panels (2kw) and no batteries to operate all those motors, actuadores, sensors, transreceivers and energy needed to keep the Hydrazine and Dinitrogen tetroxide at its operating temperature. The quantity and the location of the boosters will not provide 3-axis maneuvering required for attitude and orbital positioning. The telescopic / hydraulic rods used to deploy the sun shields are the worst design since they are vulnerable to vibration, stress and more importantly to extreme temperature variations. It seems that this satellite, just like all other satellites, will be mounted on a platform hanging from a high altitude balloon that supplies the power needed for its operation. As you saw in the videos, the builders are able to lift the 6+ tons satellite by holding it to its one side, which means this is not a design for weightless structure, but is a design to hold the satellite by its mounting bracket.
So 26 years to build something with a ten year life expectancy

In physics, coherence means stasis, therefore notions of an expanding universe are categorically incoherent. The universe doesn't "expand", nor can such a description have meaning whatsoever. A coherent model of the universe describes objects and time scales as contracting relative to a static (coherent) cosmic background.

In the coherent, "contracting" model of the universe, each quantum-scale event is a "rescaling" event, thereby inducing "relativity" (frame dilation) and "dark" matter & energy (accelerated expansion and anomalous galaxy rotation) as logically-required aspects of reality-theory rather than mysteries cloaked via an incoherent (expanding) model. 109,000 "likes" and not a single "dislike." In a world where social media tries ever harder each day to polarize us, to find that which we will argue about, to blind us to how similar and on-common-ground we all really are, seeing such a tremendous consensus - 109k likes without a single dislike - restores some of my faith in our humanity (I say "faith", free of any secular OR religious meaning... the fact that it seems reasonable to even add this little statement speaks to the issue).

Not even a single troll, accidental dislike, or anything.

And to see this consensus surrounding a topic that truly is so universally beneficial while at the same time benign, adds to it. The technological advances that come from these generational scientific experiments benefit us all, public, private, person, business, government, etc. The knowledge we'll gain brings us closer to a level of understanding that will help us to ensure that, if we encounter a great filter, it's less likely that it'll be a societal one (but debatably closer to a scientific one. J/k).

Brilliant video, one thing I think I can add about the red-shifting is that there is another effect causing it besides the Doppler effect. We know space is expanding, and because of that, the wavelength of light as it travels in space keeps increasing (red-shifting). The further away an object is from earth, the more it's original wavelength is red-shifted until it reaches Earth because it's light traveled longer in an expanding space.

That little nugget from Dr. Mather is such a special one.  Of course it doesn't even come close to painting the whole picture of this observatory.  I spent the first 8 Years of my career as an engineer on this satellite developing the membrane material use in the Sunshield (I may very well have worked with Destin father in Alabama).  I can honestly say that the main reason that Dr. Mather is so calm in all this is that absolutely everything has been scrutinized in making this observatory come to life.  My job was to take pretty much every engineers input, including my own, on what could fail with the sunshield material and then determine a way to prove that it wouldn't be a major failure mechanism in the target mission life.  This was by far the most challenging but oh so rewarding program I will work on in my lifetime for sure.   I unfortunately left before flight hardware was being integrated, but it is something I am very proud and humbled to have been able to be a part of.  I know this mission will succeed because there are so many very talented, smart and dedicated people that have worked on it over the past 20+ years.  I can not wait to see what it teaches us as it should be quite literally jaw dropping.  (As a side note, I was critiqued long ago by Dr. Mather in some design reviews and his presence, humbleness, and insights are exactly what you get in this interview.  It also was indicative of all of the main NASA scientists and engineers.  I wish the public got to see more of this side of things as they are truly great examples of what it is to be an American)

Members of my family tend to have anxiety issues. Nothing major, we just tend to worry about things we really shouldn't or let our imaginations go to the worst case scenario too easily.

I've come up with some simple questions to ask myself when I start to notice that I'm becoming anxious about something:

1: Does it affect me or people I care about?

2: If so, is there anything I can do about it?

3: If not, is there anything I can do to mitigate the effects from it?

If the answer to question one is no, then I try not to worry about it. If the answer to questions 2 or 3 are yes, then I get to work. Otherwise, again, I try not to worry so much.

The explanation of redshift is completely inaccurate. Speed of light is constant, it does not depend on the relative motion of the objects. Red shift is caused by the expansion of space. The distant star could be moving towards us, but the light would still have been red shifted by the expansion of space just as much as if the star were moving away from us. It's not like stars on one side of a distant spiral galaxy have their light shifted a different amount then stars on the other side just because they happen to be moving towards or away from us. The light is red shifted because space is stretching and the light is stretching with that space as it travels through it.

Also, not that this was said, but the emphasis that the star moving away from us causes the red shift has to make one think that a star moving towards us would cause a blue shift? I love the idea, but there's a reason you've never heard of a "blue shift" before

I met Dr. Mather in an elevator at a physics conference for undergrads before the pandemic. There were at least 15 students plus him squeezed into this elevator, and I don't think anybody recognized him because he hadn't done his talk about the JWST yet (at least nobody said anything). I noticed that he was wearing a small gold nobel prize pin (you can see it in the video), and I said "I like your pin". He replied "not many people have one". After this, the rest of the students realized they were standing next to a nobel laureate, and everybody was talking at once. Sadly my floor was next and I had to get off. I feel a bit sorry for blowing his cover, but it's definitely a moment I'll never forget.

Great discussion with an enthusiastic, well-spoken and clear, and humble leader in the project. I would like to hear something more about the red shift. The analogy of sound and the doppler shift putting the departing sound into a lower register is well understood to most anyone with ears, and seems at first glance to work as an illustration. Perhaps it does. But sound changes speed in several ways; through different media (almost twice as fast in water), and then from the departing source. could you hear direct sound from a plane departing at the speed of sound? Would light really act in the same way as sound? If it moves slower in relationship to us when sent from a departing source, isn't it really possible that light does not have a single speed? But if it doesn't move slower, then how an there be red shift? What if two light sources were EACH moving at more than half of the speed of light away from each other would ; would the light be slower as each saw it? Would it be visible at all? Seems to me that an interesting experiment that could be done in this regard would be to send two nuclear electric plasma engine rockets in opposite directions for a year with their lights on, and just measure the frequencies between them.  I'd also like to see light experiments using two sensors connected to a third, equidistant, time regulation broadcaster, to eliminate the variable of the timer in light speed measurements. Please excuse the amateur nature of my thoughts and questions. I would love input!

Regarding the perspective comments toward the end about whether Mather is nervous; I want to point out that this may be a huge undertaking, but it is not very high stakes for Mather himself. Whether the project succeeds or fails, he still has his Nobel prize, his family, his house(s), the money he’s accumulated over a lifetime of leading massive technical projects, etc. Whether the launch succeeds or goes poorly, his life will be minimally impacted. In fact, his life may be more impacted by a dental cavity or a flooded basement than by anything that could go well or poorly on launch day.

Let’s honor respect this great man for his tremendous technical and leadership successes, for his humility, and for his generosity in speaking with Destin. But let’s not be surprised that an accomplished man in a privileged position is not nervous about failure when failure does impact him much.

Even though the Doppler effect is a great example of frequency shifting, it's not what's going on with most redshifting. It's a common misconception, even under physicists.

The universe expanding doesn't cause actual relative motion between objects. What it does is changing the notion of distance itself. So, as a photon travels though the expanding universe, it's frequency changes with this expansion (and it actually loses energy, where does it go?).

Another important thing is that, no matter what, a photon will always travel at c relative to any observer, so there is never a change in relative velocity of the photon!

Wow, this is fantastic! I've been following the progress of the JWST from time to time, and the closer it gets to launch the more nervous I get. The launch is the most dangerous event for any space vehicle, and I hadn't ever checked to see what was going to put it into space, but it turns out to be an Ariane 5. It's a European heavy-lift space launch vehicle developed and operated by Arianespace for the European Space Agency (ESA). How reliable is the launch vehicle? Wow, it's pretty good! The rocket had a streak of 82 consecutive successful launches between 9 April 2003 and 12 December 2017, and I wondered why the specific dates, and it turns out the streak was broken on 25 January 2018 when two satellites experienced a launch anomaly -- but they were able to attain their desired orbits nevertheless. So, I'd guess one would be betting on a long-shot if one were to bet against a successful launch.

I came here instantly when I recognized my old boss, John Mather, in the thumbnail.
I was fortunate to have joined the CoBE (Cosmic Background Explorer) project from '86 to '96, which Dr. M. was the P.I. of – Principal Investigator, along with being the P.I. of the FIRAS instrument on CoBE.
And for which he and George Smoot, P.I. of the DMR instrument on CoBE, shared the 2006 Nobel Prize in Physics.

The ability to explain sometimes complex concepts in physics & instrumentation, in a way that's accessible to most folks, is a rare talent, and is manifest in Dr. Mather, as your interview brought out so beautifully.

Mission profile leaves a window of vulnerability. There have been MANY cases of mechanical parts of spacecraft failing to unfold or reconfigure after launch. A safer profile would be to put it FIRST in a parking orbit alongside the International Space Station. THEN let it unfold and reconfigure. If the operation is successful, fine. Otherwise there will be HUMAN HANDS available to fix the problem. After successful reconfiguration, it could be sent to its permanent orbit at L2.

In addition to Doppler Redshifting, let's also not forget about Halton Arp's interpretation of Intrinsic Redshifting, in that with certain galactic objects, its redshift value was a function not of velocity, but of the age of the material itself. Newly-born galaxies coming out of Quasar Galaxies were measured to have a higher blue-shift value, and then as those objects aged and settled in their new orbits as companion galaxies around their parent galaxy, would increasingly show higher red-shift values.

I used to operate thermal vacuum (space simulation) chambers when I was a young engineering technician at Martin Marietta Space Systems in the 80s.  At the time, the chamber at the Waterton campus was the second largest in the world.  And it had enough radiant illumination/heating (sun simulation) from Xenon arc lamps, that it could simulate one AND A HALF suns' worth of radiation with nearly the same broad spectrum as the sun.  The custom-made Varian diffusion pumps were so big you could have climbed into one if you'd been allowed to, and there were many of them.  They also had one of the largest acoustic vibe labs in the world, using the big Wyle modulators and horn systems.

It's not "a thermal vacuum".  It's a thermal vacuum CHAMBER.  Sometimes I wonder whether mister host understands the words he's using or if he just reads whatever is put in front of him. Destin..... you brushed on a subject there that I think you would really enjoy doing with your websight.

Redshift. When a physicist says "describe redshift" he is not referring to the grade school version. His thought automatically comes from the learned practice of actually having done so. Just about every youtube video about redshift, including those mentioning Albert Einstein insist on mentioning redshift in the most rudimentary explanation. The fact is that redshift measurements involve very precise metrology.

So, what I assume you would enjoy and it is a rather inexpensive project, is building a spectrograph. Only here we have a need for a spectrograph with a little bit of a twist. Your youtube spectrograph should be able to measure a sample in your lab and measure a comparison material while looking down a telescope SIMULTANEOUSLY! Both images should be measured on the same CCD or piece of film at the same time. Then the results can be measured and the results directly compared over long periods of time. (Is our star in orbit around a black hole? Is Betelgeuse expanding more quickly this month than it was last?)

Really, give it some thought. All you need is a pile of old broken film SLR parts, a beam splitter, your old digital camera and any old pair of binoculars. I'm sure you can silver a piece of glass and burn a slot in it with a laser....other than that....well, redshift isn't really measured by a traffic cop with a gun either. (Don't forget to get the sound of the start of the Indy 500, everybody misses that one.)

Red shift CAN'T be caused by speed because the speed of light is CONSTANT!  The only thing I can think of that might cause red shift is that the frequency of the light slows with distance traveled. This has bothered me for many years and indicates the the whole expanding universe theory is based on nonsense. Reiterating, if the speed of light is constant, red shift can't be caused by the directional vector of distant objects. BTW, the same thing applies for blue shift.

In 2011 I was in 5th grade and one of my classmate's father worked at Goddard, working on the JWST, he came in for career day or something and spoke to us at length about the new space telescope. What exactly he did I can't quite remember (This was 10 years ago.) Then a year later at some family gathering my mom introduced me to a friend of hers who worked at Goddard, and he gave my grandfather and I a tour of the facilities (at least the ones we were allowed access to) and I didn't know this at the time, but we got to see glimpses of some of the small parts that were going to be put into the JWST.

Reading news of the JWST program and hearing of the launch later this December, has a small personal connection for me. It is a grand endevour that will (god-willing) eclipse even the success of the Hubble Space Telescope.

It's funny. His comment at the end about not worrying about things directly echoes something that Chris Hadfield covered in his masterclass (which is well worth a watch if you get a chance). Someone asked him if he ever got worried or scared when he was strapped on top of what was effectively a giant bomb on a launchpad and his answer was 'no', because he had trained as much as possible, practiced every scenario and at that point there was nothing else he could do to effect the outcome. What was going to happen was going to happen, so you have to stop worrying about things you can't control and just enjoy the ride.

You don't need to be 70 to reach that conclusion. I had the same conclusion at 7, and I'm not unique. Worrying is a physical state that does not benefit you. Looking out for possible pitfalls and trying to prepare for them within reasonable limits does. So, once you have invested what makes sense, there is no point worrying about it any more. For instance, this is what is reflected in risk management in business. Simply put, you assess risks as well as you can. You check what it takes to avoid bad things or reduce the consequences. Make a decision whether it's worth it or not. You execute the steps that make sense. Then you go on and do your business.

The zen of doing everything as best as possible is really helped by the fact that they were able to delay over and over until they got it right. That's another valuable lesson that's not quite as universally applicable, but we could still all benefit from. If you need to have the best plan, you need the time to research it, improve it, and implement it, and you cannot know how long that will be until it is done.

The inverse is also useful - try over and over and fail as fast as you can, which is basically what SpaceX is doing for orbital launches. They're both great strategies, but they only work for specific problem domains. Wisdom is knowing which domain you're working in.

I've been following the development of the JWST for years now and I am so excited for this thing to go to space. Ever since I got interested in it, I realised that some of the people involved in the project have been working on this for years and years and I could never really stop worrying about the fact that rockets tend to fail some of the time and if they do, there is nothing you can do to save the payload. I could only imagine the heartache of losing something you spent years of your life working on to some kind of probably minute failure ending catastrophically. I have the utmost respect for John Mather for actually convincing me that at least one person who has been on this project since the beginning is not fearful of the launch but rather calm and collected towards what will happen, either way. I think this takes a tremendous amount of willpower on a project like this, considering the time of your life you have invested in it.
I am so looking forward to the launch and I will certainly spend every second of the critical phase alongside all of the people involved in this, mentally. Best of luck to all of you and the JWST! Can't wait for the first images!

Nice story, glad you got the opportunity to see the labs and especially to speak with John. Not only is he a highly accomplished Nobel Laureate, he is one of the best teachers you will ever meet, and very generous with his time.
If you are curious about the story of trying to get big cosmology projects to uncover the mystery of the beginnings of the universe, there is an easy read that doesn't require an engineering or physics background. It tells the story of Cosmic Background Explorer that set out to prove The Big Bang.
In "The Very First Light", John explains "big science" in a way that helps most of us understand what it takes to "see" back in time to the very first light of The Big Bang and beyond. It is a fascinating story and well worth your time.
This is pretty incredible.

Being able to 'make the best plan for every outcome you could possibly think of' is also a luxury. This is why James Webb telescope launch was delayed so many times, to make sure they don't fail.

Most projects don't have that pressure of '1 mistake and most of your work turns into trash' so they don't get the luxury of being able to plan for and work out every possible failure.

It's especially frustrating in IT development these days. The industry has learned that the cost of failure is often low, so now businesses prioritize speed over quality, forcing the developers to pump out poorly designed garbage.

all i can say is, I HOPE THEY PUT CERAMIC BEARINGS (OR SILICON NITRIDE) IN THE REACTION WHEELS ON THE JWST, INSTEAD OF STEEL ONES Silicon nitride or Ceramic bearings (being non-conducting) will not spall and pit (like metallic ones) from arcing, due to ionizing solar and cosmic radiation, which would otherwise cause the reaction wheels - and eventually the ENTIRE MISSION - to prematurely FAIL. NASA, it's not too late....use ceramic bearings in the reaction wheels, not metallic ones. Too many NASA space telescope and probe missions have failed prematurely, due to reaction wheel failure - because conductive, metal bearings were used.

The graphics, for example at 14:35, show circles that are shifted in a way that is appropriate for a motion induced doppler shift but a color change along the line of sight appropriate for a expansion induced shift. This conflates the two effects and we get the mistaken image, shown along the line of sight, that the color changes but the wavelength doesn't.

What he talked about at the end, about having a plan for everything, reminds me of something Chris Hadfield talks about in his book. He relates a story on being blinded on a space walk, but instead of panicking, he and others figured it out (it was basically soap from cleaning the visor, iirc, and they managed to get it cleared out of his eyes, finished the walk, and safely back in). Instead of getting upset, everyone worked on a solution so that it wouldn't happen again, but if it did, they would know what the issue was and how to solve it.

The IBEX satellite falsified all 40 assumptions it was sent up to confirm about the sun. And showed us the best minds on the subject didn't know a thing. It so red-pilled the Junior Vice President at Lockhead that was in charge of the project that he set up a his own non profit and funded the SAFIRE project. Within 8 years a team of engineers built a star in a vacuum chamber that perfectly matched the features of the sun and even was able to create the heavier elements in its plasma atmosphere. These satellites are a double edged sword, the more they send up the more they falsify the standard model and its assumptions. The key here is to keep an open mind and understand that accepted theory can and will be contradicted. I really hope the dogmas and bias' of these brilliant scientists do not stand in the way of contradictory findings.

10:27 "It's a small amount of pressure. Like a thousandth of a gram on a square meter"

I really admire that you're using SI units, but unfortunately you've used the wrong unit here. Or missed some additional wording to disambiguate it. :P

Mass m [kg] != Force F [N] != Pressure p [Pa]
Pressure is force per area, force is mass times acceleration: p = F/A = (m*a)/A

You're talking about pressure here, using a mass unit. Okay, to be fair, you already took out the area by explicitly mentioning it, but that still leaves a force, not a mass.

"A thousandth of a gram on a square meter" combined with earth's accelleration would then become 9.81 mN/m^2 ~ 10 mN/m^2 = 10^(-2) N/m^2 = 10^(-2) Pa
I know, saying "one hundredth Pascal" isn't as intuitive, but just adding something like "for comparison, we live in an atmospheric pressure of around 10 kPa" should be enough to give a good idea.

I know that US Americans love to measure forces in mass units by implicitly assuming "equivalent to the force of this mass on earths surface", but technically it's just the wrong use of the unit. Not disambiguating between mass and force is kinda understandable, since gravity is (to a small tolerance) equal everywhere we live. However, especially in space's (seemingly) zero gravity, there is no (relative) acceleration to measure this. Every force measured by mass would be zero.

Even the official US American pressure unit "pound(s) per square inch" does that, which I find really, really frustrating. Because it normalizes the misconception of mass = force even more.

Sorry for being that obnoxious "well, actually..." guy. But I feel like this hole needed to be closed, especially in an environment like this, where learning, science and precision are emphasized.
This physical dimension disambiguation is just one of the things I wish was more ingrained into common knowledge. Just like the difference between kB, MB, GB, ... and kiB, MiB, GiB, ... (which is an important distinction, but similarly ambiguous, since the vast majority uses GB when they in fact mean GiB). But most people don't care, which makes technical communication imprecise.

All right, rant over. Sorry again. I hope I didn't strike too many nerves here and gave someone the opportunity to learn something. :P

As someone who's generally not worried about things, I believe the interpretation is a bit off, there's no emotion to release, why?  Because the investment has already been spent.  "A lot riding on this" isn't really true, there's absolutely nothing riding on it.  If it blows up on launch pad nothing is lost--remember the sunk cost fallacy.  The investment has already been spent, it's gone regardless of the outcome.  As such, the result is kinda' a moot point.  Would it be preferable and exciting to gain insights from it all succeeding though?  Of course!  But having artificial emotional stress over something uncontrollable in the moment serves nothing.

I hate to be a pedant, but I want to point out that the redshift that the Prof is talking about is mostly Cosmological redshift as opposed to relativistic redshift (aka Doppler effect) that you explain. Love the video, but what you described as 'redshift' is actually just the Doppler Effect for light. Redshift or 'cosmological redshift' occurs in a similar manner, but it is not the fact that the objects in the universe are moving away from us, it is that the space in-between us and the object is actually stretching due to the expansion of the universe.

Actually your definition of reaction wheels is inaccurate at 9:55 since the wheels do NOT need to constantly rotate. There are different types of momentum wheels: passive, active or zero momentum wheels. The reaction wheels are a zero momentum control type which means they can rotate or stay still in order to keep the momentum at zero. They require a different type of attitude control in order to be discharged (called momentum dumping), meaning if the wheels need to spin too fast because you've accumulated too much momentum, you fire the thrusters (or a different type of active attitude control with high authority) and slow or stop the wheels. The kind of wheel that is kept rotating, is an ACTIVE momentum wheel which means the wheel constantly rotate in order to give the spacecraft gyroscopic tenacity, but cannot be controlled to stabilize the spacecraft.

Small correction to your redshift explaination: Your example of the moving emergency vehicle is called "the doppler effect". Here your explaination is correct. Light does NOT show the doppler effect. The redshift happens because the space itself is expanding. not because stars move away from us. Because stars move away from us even without the universe expanding, but that movement doesn't cause any redshift. The light redshift and the doppler effect are two completely different phenomena although their effect looks to be the same.

The FSM isn't just there for stabilization, its other purpose (actually you might say its primary purpose) is to allow you to have a larger FOV in the image created by your optical system than your focal plane array covers.  If you sized the total image exactly to your FPA, that would limit your resolution over the optical FOV to only the number of pixels in the FPA or require a massive FPA to cover the entire image at the desired resolution.  If you oversize the image created by the optical system with respect to the FPA, you can use the FSM to steer the image around on the FPA, giving you the full resolution of the FPA over smaller chunks of the optical system's FOV.  So the instantaneous FOV of the FPA is much smaller than the FOV of the optics, but you can use the FSM to move the FPA FOV around within the optical system's total FOV.

And he is right. Just like with JWST. As it is loaded off to the rocket all everyone can say is we did our best. We tried to come up with every failure and rigorously tested to be as confidant as can be that it won't fail. There is a lot of moving parts involved in just getting it to unfold. But they've done multiple tests to make sure it won't. And have plans built and ready incase something does. That is the role of the redundant systems. You didn't mention it, but I remember there was a collective facepalm when news that something like 100 screws fell out when it was on the shake table. But that was the whole point of the shake table. That was working through a plan to make sure nothing shook apart during launch such that it can't unfold itself. Same goes for the sound chamber.
